name: First Conditional
explanation: Used for real and possible future situations. Exams test tense sequence errors in if-clauses.
structure: If + present simple, will + base verb
keyPoints: Comma used when if-clause comes first
examples: If it rains, we will stay home.
If you study, you will pass.
If she calls, I will answer.

incorrect.sentence: If it will rain, we will stay home.

questions.question: If she ____ hard, she will succeed.
Correct sentence:
options: If he comes, I will help.
If he will come, I will help.
If he came, I will help.
If he coming, I will help.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: If you try, you will win.
If she studies, she will pass.
If he will call, I will answer.
If it rains, we will cancel.

name: Second Conditional
explanation: Used for unreal or hypothetical present/future situations. Exams test wrong tense combinations.
structure: If + past simple, would + base verb
examples: If I were rich, I would travel.
If she studied, she would pass.
If they tried, they would succeed.

incorrect.sentence: If I would be rich, I would travel.

questions.question: If I ____ you, I would apologize.
Correct sentence:
options: If she studied, she would pass.
If she would study, she would pass.
If she studies, she would pass.
If she study, she would pass.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: If I were you, I would leave.
If he tried, he would win.
If she would come, I would help.
If they studied, they would pass.

name: Passive Voice (Present & Past)
explanation: Passive voice focuses on action rather than doer. Exams test wrong auxiliary forms.
examples: The work is completed.
The letter was written by him.
The cake was baked.

incorrect.sentence: The work is complete by him.

name: Reported Speech (Statements)
explanation: When reporting speech, tense often shifts back. Exams test tense consistency errors.
examples: He said he was tired.
She said she would come.
They said they had finished.

incorrect.sentence: He said he is tired.

name: Defining Relative Clauses
explanation: Defining clauses give essential information. No commas used. Exams test comma misuse.
examples: The boy who won is here.
The book that I bought is good.
The car which he drives is new.

incorrect.sentence: The boy, who won is here.

questions.question: Choose correct:
options: The book that I read is good.
The book, that I read is good.
The book that, I read is good.
The book I read, is good.

questions.question: Which is correct?
options: The man who lives here is kind.
The man, who lives here is kind.
The man who, lives here is kind.
The man lives here who is kind.

name: Third Conditional
explanation: Used for unreal situations in the past (regret or imagination). Exams test wrong auxiliary combinations.
structure: If + had + past participle, would have + past participle
examples: If I had studied, I would have passed.
If she had left early, she would have caught the train.
If they had tried, they would have succeeded.

incorrect.sentence: If I would have studied, I would have passed.
incorrect.explanation: Do not use 'would have' in if-clause.

questions.question: If she ____ harder, she would have won.
Correct sentence:
options: If he had come, I would have helped.
If he would have come, I would help.
If he came, I would have helped.
If he had come, I will help.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: If I had known, I would have acted.
If she had studied, she would have passed.
If they would have tried, they would have succeeded.
If he had arrived, we would have started.

name: Mixed Conditionals
explanation: Mixed conditionals combine different time frames (past condition + present result or vice versa). Exams test tense mismatch.
structure: If + had + past participle, would + base verb (present result)
examples: If I had studied, I would be successful now.
If she had left earlier, she would be here now.
If they had worked harder, they would have better jobs.

incorrect.sentence: If I had studied, I would have successful now.

questions.question: If she had studied medicine, she ____ a doctor now.
Identify correct:
options: If I had tried, I would be better now.
If I tried, I would have been better.
If I had try, I would be better.
If I try, I would be better.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: If he had worked harder, he would be rich now.
If she had left earlier, she would have arrived on time.
If they had studied, they would be engineers.
If I had known, I would be prepared now.
questions.explanation: Second clause refers to past; not mixed properly.

name: Gerunds vs Infinitives
explanation: Some verbs take gerunds (verb+ing), others take infinitives (to + verb). Exams test verb pattern confusion.
examples: I enjoy reading.
She wants to leave.
They decided to try.

incorrect.sentence: She enjoys to read.

name: Collective Nouns
explanation: Collective nouns (team, family, committee) can take singular or plural verbs depending on meaning. Exams test agreement logic.
examples: The team is winning.
The team are arguing among themselves.
The committee has decided.

incorrect.sentence: The team are winning the match (as one unit).
incorrect.explanation: Singular verb preferred when acting as one.

name: Misplaced Modifiers
explanation: A modifier must clearly refer to the word it describes. Exams heavily test unclear or illogical modifiers.
structure: Modifier placed next to the word it describes
examples: Running quickly, she caught the bus.
I saw a man with a telescope.
Covered in dust, the car looked old.

incorrect.sentence: Running quickly, the bus was caught by her.

questions.question: Correct sentence:
options: Running quickly, she caught the bus.
Running quickly, the bus was caught.
She caught the bus running quickly it.
The bus running quickly she caught.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: Covered in dust, the car looked old.
Walking home, I saw a cat.
Driving fast, the tree hit the car.

name: Parallel Structure
explanation: Parallel structure means using the same grammatical form in lists or comparisons. Exams heavily test imbalance in verb forms.
examples: She likes reading, writing, and dancing.
He wants to study, to work, and to travel.
They bought apples, oranges, and bananas.

incorrect.sentence: She likes reading, to write, and dancing.

questions.question: Correct sentence:
options: He likes swimming, running, and cycling.
He likes swimming, to run, and cycling.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: He wants to eat and to sleep.
They like singing, dancing, and to act.
I bought milk, bread, and eggs.

questions.question: Choose correct:
options: To run, to swim, and to jump
To run, swimming, and to jump

name: Present Perfect vs Past Simple
explanation: Use present perfect for unspecified time; use past simple for specific completed time. Exams test time markers.
structure: Have/has + past participle vs past tense
keyPoints: No specific time with present perfect
examples: I have finished my work.
I finished my work yesterday.
She has already left.

incorrect.sentence: I have finished yesterday.
incorrect.explanation: Specific past time needs past simple.

questions.question: Correct:
options: I finished the task last night.

name: Subjunctive Mood
explanation: Subjunctive expresses wishes, demands, or hypothetical situations. Exams test 'were' and base verb after that.
structure: If I were... | It is important that he be...
examples: If I were you, I would apologize.
It is essential that he be present.
I suggest that she study.

incorrect.sentence: It is important that he is present.

questions.question: If I ____ you, I would leave.
It is essential that she ____ on time.
Identify error:
options: If I were rich, I would travel.
It is necessary that she attends.

name: Inversion after Negative Adverbs
explanation: After negative adverbs (Never, Rarely, Hardly), we invert subject and auxiliary. Exams test missing inversion.
examples: Never have I seen such beauty.
Rarely does he arrive on time.
Hardly had she left when he called.

incorrect.sentence: Never I have seen such beauty.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: Hardly had she left when he called.
Never have I seen such chaos.

name: Advanced Correlative Conjunctions
explanation: Correlative conjunctions work in pairs (not only...but also, both...and). Exams test agreement and parallelism.
structure: Not only A but also B
examples: Not only did she sing but also danced.
Both Ram and Shyam are here.
Either you or he is responsible.

incorrect.sentence: Not only she sang but also danced.

questions.question: Correct sentence:
options: Not only did he win but also broke the record.
Not only he won but also broke the record.
He not only won but also broke the record.
Not only won he but also broke record.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: Both she and I are ready.
Either he or I am wrong.
Not only she sings but also dances.

name: Participle Clauses
explanation: Participle clauses shorten relative clauses. They must logically refer to the subject of the main clause.
examples: Walking down the street, I saw a dog.
Given enough time, she will finish.
Having completed the task, he left.

incorrect.sentence: Walking down the street, the dog barked at me.

questions.question: Correct sentence:
options: Walking home, the bag was lost.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: Running fast, the bus was caught.

questions.question: Past participle clause example:
options: Broken by the storm, the tree fell.
Breaking by the storm, the tree fell.

name: Causative Verbs (Have/Get Something Done)
explanation: Causative structures show that someone arranges for another person to do something.
examples: I had my car repaired.
She got her hair cut.
They have their house painted.

incorrect.sentence: I had my car repair.

name: Ellipsis and Substitution
explanation: Ellipsis omits repeated words when meaning is clear. Exams test incomplete or incorrect omission.
structure: So do I / Neither do I
examples: I like tea, and so does she.
He doesn’t like coffee, and neither do I.
She can swim, and so can I.

incorrect.sentence: I like tea, and so she does.

questions.question: She likes coffee, and so ____ I.
He can't swim, and neither ____ I.

name: Advanced Prepositions (Dependent Prepositions)
explanation: Certain verbs, adjectives, and nouns require specific prepositions. Exams test incorrect combinations.
structure: Interested in | Depend on | Good at
examples: She is interested in music.
He depends on his parents.
They are good at math.

incorrect.sentence: She is interested on music.

name: Nominalisation
explanation: Nominalisation turns verbs or adjectives into nouns. Exams test overly complex or unclear sentences.
examples: The decision was final.
Her failure shocked everyone.
The approval was granted.

incorrect.sentence: The decide was final.
incorrect.explanation: Verb must be converted to noun.

name: Cleft Sentences
explanation: Cleft sentences are used to emphasize a specific part of a sentence. Exams test wrong structure or missing 'that/who'.
structure: It + be + emphasized part + that/who + clause
examples: It was John who broke the vase.
It is honesty that matters.
It was yesterday that we met.

incorrect.sentence: It was John broke the vase.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: It was she won the prize.
It was today that we met.

questions.question: It was in Paris ____ we met.

name: Reduced Relative Clauses
explanation: Relative clauses can be reduced using participles. Exams test incorrect reduction.
structure: The man who is running → The man running
examples: The boy playing outside is my brother.
The book written by her is famous.
Students studying hard will succeed.

incorrect.sentence: The boy is playing outside is my brother.

questions.question: The girl ____ in the park is my cousin.
Identify error:
options: The man standing there is tall.
The book written by her is good.
The boy is playing there is my friend.

name: Modal Perfect (Should Have / Could Have / Might Have)
explanation: Modal perfect forms express regret, missed opportunity, or possibility in the past.
examples: You should have studied.
He could have won.
They might have missed the bus.

incorrect.sentence: You should have study.

name: Future Perfect & Future Continuous
explanation: Future perfect shows completion before a future time. Future continuous shows action in progress at a future time.
structure: Will have + past participle | Will be + verb-ing
examples: I will have finished by 5 PM.
They will be traveling tomorrow.
She will have completed the project.

incorrect.sentence: I will have finish by 5 PM.

questions.question: By next week, she ____ the task.
Identify error:
options: I will have finished by noon.

name: Advanced Comparisons
explanation: Advanced comparison structures include 'the more...the more', 'as...as', and double comparatives. Exams test incorrect forms.
examples: The more you practice, the better you become.
She is as tall as her sister.
He is better than me.

incorrect.sentence: She is more better than him.

questions.question: Correct sentence:
options: The more you study, the better you score.
The more you study, better you score.
More you study, the better you score.
The more study, the better score.

questions.question: She is ____ tall as her sister.
Identify error:
options: She is more better than him.
The faster you run, the sooner you arrive.
This book is as good as that one.

questions.question: Correct:
options: He is more better than I.

name: Appositives
explanation: An appositive is a noun or noun phrase that renames another noun. Exams test comma misuse and redundancy.
examples: My brother, a doctor, lives abroad.
Shakespeare, the famous playwright, wrote Hamlet.
The poet Robert Frost wrote many poems.

incorrect.sentence: My brother a doctor lives abroad.

questions.question: Correct sentence:
options: My sister, a teacher, works here.
My sister a teacher works here.
My sister, a teacher works here.
My sister a teacher, works here.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: Paris, the capital of France, is beautiful.

name: Conditionals Without 'If'
explanation: In formal English, 'if' can be omitted and inversion used. Exams test incorrect inversion.
examples: Had I known, I would have acted.
Were she here, she would help.
Should you need help, call me.

incorrect.sentence: Had I knew, I would have acted.

questions.question: Correct inversion:
options: Had I known, I would have acted.
Had I knew, I would have acted.
If had I known, I would act.
Had known I, I would act.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: Should you need help, call me.
Were I you, I would apologize.
Had he went, he would succeed.
Had she studied, she would pass.

name: Advanced Reporting Verbs
explanation: Advanced reporting verbs (admit, deny, suggest, insist) change structure. Exams test wrong verb patterns.
examples: He admitted stealing the money.
She suggested that he go early.
They insisted that she stay.

incorrect.sentence: He admitted to steal the money.

name: Discourse Markers
explanation: Discourse markers connect ideas logically (however, therefore, moreover). Exams test wrong logical connectors.
examples: He was tired; however, he continued.
It was raining; therefore, we stayed inside.
Moreover, she agreed.

incorrect.sentence: He was tired, therefore he continued.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: It was late; therefore, we left.
He was tired; however, he continued.
She studied hard; however, she passed easily.
It rained; therefore, the match was canceled.

name: Cohesion and Coherence
explanation: Cohesion refers to grammatical linking; coherence refers to logical flow. Exams test unclear connections.
examples: John bought a car. He loves it.
It was raining; therefore, we stayed home.
She studied hard. As a result, she passed.

incorrect.sentence: John bought a car. They love it.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: John bought a book. He read it.
The dog barked. It was loud.
Mary met Anna. They was happy.

name: Emphatic Do (Do-Support for Emphasis)
explanation: The auxiliary 'do/does/did' can be used to add emphasis to positive statements. Exams test incorrect tense or agreement.
examples: I do like this song.
She does understand the problem.
He did complete the work.

incorrect.sentence: She does understands the problem.
incorrect.explanation: Main verb must remain base form.

name: Double Negatives
explanation: Standard English avoids double negatives. Two negatives create incorrect emphasis unless stylistic.
examples: I do not know anything.
She has nothing to say.
He never arrives late.

incorrect.sentence: I don't know nothing.

name: Emphasis in Conditionals (Only If / Even If)
explanation: 'Only if' restricts condition; 'even if' shows unexpected condition. Exams test logical meaning errors.
structure: Only if + condition | Even if + condition
examples: You can enter only if you have a ticket.
I will go even if it rains.
She succeeds only if she works hard.

incorrect.sentence: You can enter even if you don't have a ticket.

questions.question: Identify error:
options: You can pass only if you study.
I will go even if it rains.
You can enter even if you have no ticket.
She wins only if she tries.

name: Sentence Fragments
explanation: A fragment is an incomplete sentence lacking subject or verb. Exams test incomplete clauses.
structure: Complete sentence = subject + verb + complete thought
examples: Because it was raining, we stayed home.
She finished her work.
Although tired, he continued.

incorrect.sentence: Because it was raining.

questions.question: Correct sentence:
options: Although he was tired, he continued.

name: Run-On Sentences
explanation: A run-on sentence joins independent clauses without proper punctuation. Exams test comma splice errors.
examples: I was tired, so I slept.
I was tired. I slept.
I was tired; therefore, I slept.

incorrect.sentence: I was tired, I slept.

questions.question: Comma splice means:
options: Two clauses joined by comma only

name: Sentence Variety
explanation: Good writing uses different sentence structures (simple, compound, complex). Exams test repetitive or monotonous structure.
structure: Mix of simple + compound + complex sentences
examples: She studied hard. She passed the exam.
She studied hard, and she passed the exam.
Because she studied hard, she passed the exam.

incorrect.sentence: She studied hard. She studied hard. She studied hard.

questions.question: Identify repetitive structure:
options: He ran. He jumped. He stopped.

name: Mixed Conditionals
explanation: Mixed conditionals combine different time references (past condition + present result). Exams test tense confusion.
structure: If + past perfect, would + base verb
examples: If I had studied, I would be successful now.
If she were taller, she would have joined the team.
If they had left earlier, they would be here.

incorrect.sentence: If I had studied, I would have be successful now.

questions.question: Correct mixed conditional:
options: If I had studied, I would be successful now.
If I study, I would be successful.
If I had studied, I will be successful.
If I studied, I would have be successful.

questions.question: If she were taller, she would have joined the team refers to:
Identify error:
options: If I had left, I would be home now.
If she were rich, she would have traveled.
If I had studied, I will pass.
If they had trained, they would win now.

name: Hedging Language
explanation: Hedging softens statements using words like 'might', 'perhaps', 'possibly'. Common in academic writing.
structure: Modal + base verb | It seems that...
examples: It might be true.
Perhaps she misunderstood.
It seems that the results are correct.

incorrect.sentence: It is absolutely always correct without doubt.

name: Formal vs Informal Register
explanation: Formal English avoids contractions, slang, and casual expressions. Exams test inappropriate register.
structure: Formal: no contractions | Informal: contractions allowed
examples: I cannot attend the meeting.
We regret to inform you.
It is unacceptable.

incorrect.sentence: I can't make it, sorry bro.

name: Redundancy and Conciseness
explanation: Redundancy means unnecessary repetition. Concise writing removes extra words without changing meaning.
examples: We met before.
This is essential.
He returned.

incorrect.sentence: He returned back again.
